Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project will develop anatomical models that can be dissected to reveal internal structure and to achieve specified learning objectives. Correlated digital media will guide the user through the dissection. This innovation is in response to an international trend to reduce anatomy education at medical and dental schools, and in response to increasing facility costs and increasing awareness of the hazards of using cadaveric material. Dissectable models are tangible learning assets that replace cadaveric specimens and can offset the reduction in anatomy education in medical institutions; ensuring that medical students receive a solid grounding in the anatomical sciences. The models and adjunct materials can be adapted to other student populations including K-12, post-secondary, graduate education, and continuing medical education. The models are created using additive manufacturing to reduce costs and to allow the accurate representation of internal structure. The models are constructed of materials that mimic the tactile characteristics of the actual tissue and can be dissected, similar to the real specimens, to reveal this internal structure. The efficacy of all of these materials in learning will be assessed to improve the models and media design. The models, when paired with animations, interactive media, dissection guides, and self-assessment materials, will benefit students by maintaining tactile learning experiences in anatomy education.

This SBIR Phase I project plans to supplement or replace the tactile experience of gross anatomy dissection with the use of simulated specimens. Success will require technical advances in digital 3D model production using low-cost multihead 3D printing to achieve a scalable production of anatomical and biological models. Custom, low-cost multihead printers will be constructed that can print a specimen in multiple materials that differ in texture or color or are used as support material for the print. Achieving these technical advances will generate strong early branding and distribution advantages as market barriers to possible competitors. Technical challenges will also include the integration of specific learning objectives into the models, achieving a comparable appearance and texture of actual specimens, and maintaining sufficient low-cost for student and institutional use. The proposed models, when paired with animations, interactive media, dissection guides, and self-assessment materials, will benefit students who prefer tactile learning experiences, and will benefit institutions that are turning away from specimen dissection or cannot provide those resources. Pilot studies will help determine best practices in printing, scale of production, the structure of adjunct digital materials, curricular implementation, and marketing in Phase II. This Phase I project is an initial step in the creation of sophisticated and accurate alternatives or supplement to the use of cadaveric specimens.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Dissectables LLC was awarded a National Science Foundation (NSF) Small Business Innovation Research grant (#1621106) beginning 7/1/2016 to develop 3D printed anatomical models constructed of materials that allow a "dissection experience" similar to that available in the dissection of cadaveric materials. The advantages of 3D printing the anatomical models rather than using traditional casting methods include the ability to generate models with an accurate representation of external and internal structure and to use multiple materials that mimic the texture and consistency of cadaveric specimens. Models can be produced at relatively low cost and can be customized easily in scale and to target specific learning objectives. Dissectables models have additional advantages over actual cadaveric specimens in that they are non-hazardous and do not require special handling or storage.

Challenges that were anticipated in achieving the aims of the project were significant. The construction of suitable digital models for printing, the selection of appropriate materials for model construction, the production of a low-cost 3D printer capable of printing in multiple materials simultaneously, the generation of appropriate adjunct educational materials to accompany the models, and the assessment of the effectiveness of these models in learning in medical education were cited as technical or logistical hurdles in completing the aims of the Phase I proposal.

During the Phase I project period, we were able to accomplish, at least in part, most of the stated aims of the proposal, and are in a good position to continue our efforts under the support of an NSF SBIR Phase II award. Prototype models of heart and elbow have been created and refined through rounds of printing and design. In addition, a simple frog model is in development. During the Phase I project period, our overall efforts became two-fold. First, accurate and precise digital models were needed that fulfilled learning objectives for different levels of medical education and that could be customized to fit specific learning objectives. Previous effort had created an excellent normal human heart model. However, this model required extensive effort to move easily between different creative and printing software platforms and to allow advanced physical modeling to create digital models with regions that transitioned between materials. During the Phase I period, we were able to produce multiple digital models that overcame these challenges through consistency in modeling approach and execution. Thus, currently, we have a model that is easily modified, lacks previous expectations of printer software incompatibilities, and is designed to transition between materials at critical points. In addition, using the same modeling protocol, we have preliminary models depicting an articulated boney elbow joint, joint capsule, and musculature, as well as a frog model with gastrointestinal structure. Second, while we had previously engineered a usable 3D printer to print in specialized soft flexible material, our proposal called for the production of a 3D printer capable of printing in multiple materials of different characteristics. Our efforts here were quite successful in the production of a low-cost printer that can carry multiple print heads, however, the use of soft flexible material and the advance to more materials printing simultaneously became challenges that persisted to the end of the project period. These challenges are being addressed at the close of this Phase I period.

Our findings have provided proof of concept that we can create complex physical models of anatomical structures that mimic characteristics of cadaveric specimens. We are now able to create very complex digital models of organs that include external and internal structures that move seamlessly across the constellation of software platforms required for successful 3D printing. We have developed design methods to overcome issues of integrating structures with different physical characteristics and different support requirements into a single model. We have also produced methods to join structures printed in different materials, as well as fill patterns that adjust the texture and stiffness of different regions of the models. Our success during the Phase I period also advanced our ability to construct low-cost scalable printer capabilities, which enable the cost-effective production of a large number of models at will. Design of these printers has produced advances in material extruder design and printer hot-end capabilities resulting in proprietary printer components that may enable printing in a variety of materials, in particular, soft flexible materials that have proven difficult to use in additive manufacturing. These printer components are to be submitted by Dissectables for patent protection, thus enhancing our market advantage.

Together, our findings support the submission and consideration of a Phase II proposal in that we anticipate the successful production of printers and physical models that fit the criteria for a commercially viable product that will advance the delivery of educational objectives in advanced medical education.

 


Last Modified: 07/24/2017
Modified by: Glen Gerbush
